ZeroNet sites have a data usage limit, a user gets only a very limited amount of KB he can use to post things, it's different for every site but usually it's less than 100 KB, so a spammer will have to keep creating new accounts which can be easily banned by site owners or muted by users. An accound provider like ZeroID.bit could start taking a small fee for account creation if spam becomes too much of a problem, could be done via an anonymous crypto currency.

The spammer could make his own account provider to still keep creating as many accounts as he wants for free since ZeroNet is decentralized, but a site owner has to add this new account provider to their site for it to work so they could just decide not to support the spammer's account provider and then he has no other choice but to pay to spam which means he won't.

Normal users run into trouble with the data usage limit too, so this might go away at some point in the future, but it doesn't have to, it could just be improved so that it works better for users but not for spammers. Like resetting the limit once a month. The original reason for the limit was a technical limitation, ZeroNet didn't support transferring files in small chunks, it could only transfer the full file in one go so it had to be small or the transfer would timeout, which is why big files weren't supported until ZeroNet 0.6 came out a few days ago.

Just copy your `data/users.json` file to the other device (and make a backup of it while you are at it, that file holds all your private keys, so don't show it to anyone and don't lose it). There shouldn't be any problems, [it is the official way to do it](https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/#can-i-use-the-same-username-on-multiple-machine).

If you don't know where the file is stored, just go to [ZeroHello](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D/) (the overview site you get to when you click on the round Zero button that is in the top right corner of every ZeroNet site) and click on the three dots menu in the top left, right next to "Hello ZeroNet_" and then click on "Show data directory".

In the folder that opens is the users.json file you need to copy to the other device.
